title: Elbert Hubbard's Secret
subject: The copywriter who died on the Lusitania
author: Ben Settle
body:
In 1915, copywriter Elbert Hubbard died on the Lusitania.

He was one of the highest paid writers of his time.

And he had a secret weapon:

He never tried to convince anyone of anything.

Instead?

He just told stories.

Stories that made his point without making his point.

Here's an example:

When he wanted to sell a book about failure, he didn't write "10 Ways To Avoid Failure."

He wrote a story about a message carrier in ancient Rome who failed his mission and was executed.

The moral was obvious.

But he never stated it.

He just told the story and let readers connect the dots.

And you know what?

It worked better than any logical argument ever could.

Because stories bypass resistance.

Logic creates resistance.

This is why the best email writers rarely argue.

They just tell stories that make their point impossible to miss.

And if you don't know how to do this?

You're working way too hard to make sales.

Email Players shows you exactly how to do this.

How to tell stories that sell without "selling."

How to make points without arguing.

How to get people to convince themselves.

It's at:

www.EmailPlayers.com

Ben Settle
